Situation1: They occasionally give casual advice when asked about minor career choices.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Story: I’m tightening my boots, dust swirling around my ankles, when I spot Marcus, a new apprentice, lingering by the tool shed. He looks anxious, clutching a crumpled resume. “Hey, can I ask you something?” he says, voice low. I know he’s been struggling to decide whether to stick with construction or try for a trade school scholarship. As his mentor, I’m supposed to be there for these moments, to offer guidance, even if it’s just a few words to help him weigh his options. But the foreman’s whistle pierces the air—pre-work safety briefing in two minutes. Missing it means a write-up, maybe even a suspension, and the whole crew is counting on everyone to be present and alert. My mind races: if I stop to talk, I let down the team and risk my own standing. If I walk away, I fail Marcus when he needs me most. My heart pounds as I stand between the shed and the gathering crew, torn by the demands pulling me in opposite directions.
